hobby.message: Still folding origami to stay grounded?
Political literature still your guilty pleasure?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I fold origami... from scrap forms mostly. It helps me think... quietly.
neutral_answer: Still breathing. Routine helps. I fold paper sometimes, keeps my hands steady.
Lately, all these broadcasts make it harder to focus.
Crowds out the quiet you need for, you know, hobbies.
Yeah, still here. I fold origami—helps with nerves.
Last week, people kept arguing about scores outside my window. Ruined three cranes.
Let’s just say quiet’s in short supply lately.
I keep at it anyway. Routine matters.
Breathing, somehow. I do origami most nights, paper folding, nothing fancy.
Used to clear my head, but after the broadcast, it feels exposed.
Hard to get a crisp fold with this much noise outside.
BCI debates everywhere. Makes hobbies feel... monitored.
Barely. But yes. Folding origami is my way to decompress after work.
It’s intricate—cranes, flowers, insects. I focus on the precision of each fold.
Since Halden’s broadcast, the arguing outside throws my concentration.
Background noise gets in my fingers. My last model’s full of creases.
Even folding paper feels risky with all these system glitches.
But I can’t seem to stop. It’s all muscle memory now.
Still breathing, thanks. Honestly, folding origami is what keeps me sane some days.
I’ve been at it since I was a teenager—complex forms, modular pieces, tessellations.
Usually, it’s meditative. Lately, though, every fold’s too tight, like I’m bracing.
After Halden’s broadcast, the neighborhood won’t shut up about BCI scores and sabotage.
I ruined half my crane stack last night from trembling hands.
Sometimes I imagine every shape I fold gets flagged—ridiculous, I know, but paranoia’s... viral here.
Even my old pattern files triggered a security alert today.
But the folding helps. It’s a private logic—something I can control, even when nothing else makes sense.
hobby_answer: Yeah. Always have one, just habit now.
Mostly simple folds, nothing that catches notice.
Harder to find good paper lately, after all the system jitters.
Since the 'Halden Echoes', people watch each other too closely.
Sometimes I leave it at home, safer that way.
I do, yeah. Small one, square-base crane.
Keeps my hands busy, less noticeable than tapping on a screen.
These days, everyone looks twice if you sit and fold.
After those broadcasts, I feel eyes everywhere—especially in this neighborhood.
Not sure it's worth the attention, but I still fold.
Been switching to plain receipt slips, nothing traceable.
Got one, sure. Crane from a billing statement. Nothing fancy.
Origami’s just structure and patience. No misunderstandings if you keep it basic.
Except after Halden’s voice hit every channel, even that turned tense.
Neighbors ask too many questions if I’m folding near the window now.
Feels like every shape could mean something more. Paranoia, I guess.
Still, it calms me when things are loud—like last week’s forum yelling.
Yeah, actually. I finished a modular star on the tram earlier today.
Used to spend hours making complex tessellations, but I keep it subtle now.
The mood changed after those Echoes—people say anything intricate looks coded.
Last weekend, some kid in my block grabbed my paper, called it 'proof of subversion.'
Even the usual office gossip turned to accusations over who folds what pattern.
But folding helps when I feel hemmed in. It’s private, but... I guess that’s fragile now.
Sometimes I miss when it was just scrap art, not a signal.
Always. I learned complex modular folds to quiet my mind during long data runs.
After Halden’s messages started leaking, neighbors even flagged me for folding too much.
Security thinks origami hides codes now—like we’re transmitting in creases.
Last week, I found the diagrams I developed locked under audit, just for a stork fold.
Used to trade models with a friend in Archives, but she’s ghosted now—probably flagged.
Every piece I fold at home, I worry it’s tracked in my profile.
Even simple cranes feel risky with all the BCI paranoia around.
Still, it’s an anchor—paper, geometry, pure process. Reminds me I’m not just running patterns for the system.
If I stop folding... I’m not sure what’s left of me apart from compliance metrics.
